conclusions.summary: Engineer A's use of AI in report writing was partly ethical and partly unethical
ethical_aspects: Engineer A was competent in the domain
Thorough review and verification of AI-generated content
Ensured accuracy and compliance with professional standards
unethical_aspects: Did not obtain client permission to use confidential information in AI
Did not document required technical citations
conclusions.key_finding: Ethical use of AI to create report text must satisfy all pertinent requirements

conclusions.conclusion: Not unethical per se, but misuse was unethical
conclusions.summary: The use of AI-assisted drafting tools was not unethical per se, but Engineer A's misuse was unethical
conclusions.reasoning: Engineer A failed to maintain Responsible Charge over the AI tool and its output before sealing and providing to Client W
conclusions.key_finding: AI-assisted drafting requires at least the same level of scrutiny as human-created work

conclusions.summary: Engineer A has no professional or ethical obligation to disclose AI use to Client W
conclusions.conditions: Unless disclosure required under contract with Client W
conclusions.current_state: No universal guideline mandating AI disclosure in engineering work at time of review
conclusions.guidance: Ethical principles favor transparency when AI plays a substantial role in generating work products
conclusions.recommendation: Engineers integrating AI should adopt rigorous verification processes and consider disclosing AI involvement when significant
